newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Creditanstalt battle heats up as deadline looms.
newsitem.headline: Creditanstalt battle heats up as deadline looms.

text.p: Political infighting over the sale of Austrian sell-off candidate Creditanstalt continued on Sunday, one day before the latest tender in the six-year privatisation was about to close.

The battle for the country's flagship bank took a nasty turn on Friday when the Austrian parliament called on the government to reject a bid by arch-rival Bank Austria, opening a deep rift in the ruling centre-left coalition.

The motion was whipped through with the votes of the conservative People's Party (OeVP), the Social Democrat's (SPOe) junior coalition partner, and the far-right Freedom Party. The SPOe, together with the opposition Liberals and Greens, voted against it.

"We won't let ourselves be forced into new elections. But on the other hand, you can't reject a good offer just for the sake of (political) peace," SPOe chief whip Peter Kostelka told Austrian news agency APA. "Our patience has been exhausted."
Parliament called for a "speedy and complete privatisation" of both Creditanstalt and Bank Austria.

Bank Austria, which is effectively controlled by the City of Vienna and has close links to the SPOe, last week emerged as a last-minute bidder for the state's 70 percent voting stake in Creditanstalt, traditionally a stronghold of the conservatives.
The bid rivalled a lone offer by an Austro-Italian-German consortium led by insurer EA-Generali, which is openly favoured by the conservatives.

The group has offered some 10 billion schillings for about two-thirds of the government's 19.9 million voting shares in Creditanstalt and wants to sell the rest on the market. Bank Austria has offered 16 billion schillings for the total.

Finance Minister Viktor Klima over the weekend added a new twist to the seemingly endless sell-off saga, saying he had received a third bid for the bank. "It comes neither from Bank Austria nor from the EA-Generali consortium," he said.
The identity of all three bidders is expected to be released on Monday.
Klima, the third finance minister in succession to attempt the sale of Creditanstalt, has repeatedly said he wants to wrap up the privatisation before year-end.

Conservatives have balked at the prospect of the flagship bank being taken over by a socialist-controlled rival, supporting Creditanstalt executives and thousands of employees who turned out in force on Friday to protest against a possible takeover by Bank Austria.

Creditanstalt employees feared they would be more likely to lose their jobs since, by a quirk of Austrian law, employees of Bank Austria are protected from dismissal, effectively putting them in the same league as public servants.
The two banks' combined staff amounts to more than 14,000, prompting analysts to speculate a merger would result in some 4,000 to 5,000 job cuts.
Both banks together, with some 1,300 billion schillings in combined assets, would control 80 percent of retail banking in Austria and dominate trading on Vienna's stock exchange.
